DOCNAME: CASE OF KOSTOVSKI v. THE NETHERLANDS
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG Mr PERSON is a NORP citizen born in DATE . He has a very long criminal record , including convictions for various crimes in the GPE , notably armed robbery at a jeweller ’s shop in DATE for which he was sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .

In DATE ORG ( arrondissements- rechtbank ) had declared admissible a request by GPE for his extradition to stand trial for serious offences committed in GPE in DATE , namely QUANTITY armed robberies and assisting in an escape from a court building , involving in each case attempted manslaughter .
On DATE the applicant escaped from GPE prison together with CARDINAL PERSON and others ; he remained on the run until the following DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE CARDINAL masked men conducted an armed raid on a bank in PERSON and made off with a substantial amount of currency and cheques .

Police suspicions centred on PERSON and his associates because , being on the run , they probably needed money and because DATE previously PERSON had been directly involved in a robbery carried out at the same bank with exactly the same modus operandi as the DATE raid . These suspicions were strengthened on DATE , when the GPE police received an anonymous telephone call from a man who said :
" DATE a hold - up took place at a bank in GPE . Those responsible for the hold - up are PERSON , PERSON and a NORP . PERSON and the NORP escaped from prison in GPE in DATE . "
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE a man visited the police in GPE . The reporting officer drew up , on DATE , the following account of the interview :
" On DATE there appeared before me a man who for fear of reprisals desired to remain anonymous but whose identity is known to me . He stated as follows :

‘ DATE CARDINAL men escaped from the remand centre ( PERSON bewaring ) in GPE , among them a NORP and an PERSON . They are now living with an acquaintance of theirs in GPE . I do not know the address . They are also in touch with PERSON of GPE . The NORP and the PERSON sometimes spend TIME at PERSON home in PERSON in GPE . PERSON sleeps there TIME . The NORP and the PERSON now drive a blue ORG car ; I do not know the registration number . PERSON drives a new white ORG sports car . The NORP , the PERSON and PERSON carried out a hold - up DATE on a bank in GPE , in the course of which the staff of the bank were locked up . PERSON , who otherwise had nothing to do with the affair , takes PERSON to the CARDINAL men in GPE every day because PERSON does not have a driving licence . PERSON drives a silver - grey ORG car , registration mark CARDINAL-PF-CARDINAL.’

I wish to add that , after being shown various photographs included in the police file , he picked out photos of the following persons : PERSON ... as being the NORP to whom he had referred ; PERSON ... as being the PERSON in question . "

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the GPE police , acting on information received that PERSON was hiding with a brother of PERSON at an address in that town , conducted a search there . Whilst they found no one , they did find fingerprints of PERSON and PERSON .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE a person visited the police in GPE . The CARDINAL reporting officers drew up , on DATE , the following account of the interview :

" On DATE there appeared before us a person who for security reasons wishes to remain anonymous but whose identity is known to us . He / She stated that he / she knew that PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON , who were known to him / her , were guilty of the armed raid on a branch of ORG at ORG in PERSON on or CARDINAL DATE . CARDINAL , had been divided into more or less equal parts by PERSON , PERSON and PERSON and that PERSON had received a small part thereof . From what he / she said , this would have been about GPE . CARDINAL . The said person also stated that PERSON , PERSON and PERSON knew each other from when they were detained in GPE prison .

PERSON and PERSON escaped from the said prison on DATE and ORG was released at DATE . The said person stated that PERSON lived most of the time with PERSON at PERSON CARDINAL in GPE . PERSON and PERSON were said to have lived for a while at Oude Gracht CARDINAL in GPE , which they had rented in another name . A brother of PERSON also lived there ; he was called PERSON . The said person stated in this connection that the GPE police had raided the said LOC but had not found the above - mentioned people . He / she said that PERSON , PERSON and PERSON were in a room on a higher floor of the same building in FAC at the time of the police raid . The police had not searched that floor . The person in question also stated that PERSON was now believed to be living in GPE .
PERSON and PERSON were said to meet each other quite regularly there , near FAC , which was their usual meeting place .

According to the person in question , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON were in possession of powerful weapons . He / she knew that PERSON and PERSON each had a PERSON gun among other things and that PERSON had a revolver , possibly a Colt CARDINAL .
The person interviewed by us stated that he / she might later be able to provide more details about the above - mentioned persons and the offences they had committed . "

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE PERSON and PERSON were arrested together in GPE . They were in a car driven by one PERSON , who had helped them to escape from prison and had had various contacts with them in and after DATE .

On his arrest PERSON was in possession of a loaded revolver . Subsequently , firearms were also found in the home of PERSON , who was arrested on DATE , in the home of ORG and in another room in the house previously searched in GPE .
Like the applicant , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and ORG all have very long criminal records .

CARDINAL . ORG A preliminary judicial investigation ( gerechtelijk vooronderzoek ; see paragraph CARDINAL below ) was instituted in respect of PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON . On DATE Mr Nuboer , the examining magistrate ( rechter - commissaris ) , interviewed , in the presence of the police but in the absence of the public prosecutor and of the applicant and his counsel , the witness who had made a statement to the police in GPE on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The magistrate , who did not know the person ’s identity , considered his / her fear of reprisals to be well - founded and therefore respected his / her wish to remain anonymous . His report on the hearing recorded that the witness made the following sworn statement :

" On DATE I made a statement to the police in GPE which was included in a report drawn up on DATE . You read out that statement to me . I declared that it is the truth and that I stand by it , on the understanding that I was not aware that the bank in PERSON was at No . CARDINAL Nieuwstraat . My knowledge stems from the fact that both PERSON and PERSON , as well as PERSON , had all told me about the hold - up . They said that they had taken not only cash , but also NORP ORG cheques and ORG . I myself saw a number of the ORG . "

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the examining magistrate wrote to the lawyers acting for those concerned , enclosing copies of the official reports , including the statements of the anonymous person he had seen . He indicated that they could submit written questions on the basis of the statements made , pointing out that they would not be invited to the hearing before him . Amongst those who responded was PERSON lawyer , PERSON , who submitted CARDINAL questions in a letter of DATE .

On DATE , as a result of those questions , the anonymous witness whom Mr Nuboer had heard was interviewed again , this time by PERSON , an examining magistrate deputising for PERSON . The police were present but neither the public prosecutor nor the applicant or his counsel . The magistrate ’s report of the hearing recorded that the witness - whose anonymity was respected on this occasion also - made the following sworn statement :
" I stand by the statement which I made on DATE to the examining magistrate in GPE . My answers to the questions posed by PERSON are as follows .

I am not the person who telephoned anonymously to the police communications centre in GPE on DATE , nor the person who made a statement on DATE at the police station in GPE . I did not state to the police that I knew that the bank was at FAC in PERSON . I knew that it was in PERSON , but not the street . I learned the latter from the police and it was included as being part of my own statement by mistake . Although PERSON did not ask this , I would add that I did not inform the municipal police in GPE .

As regards the questions posed by PERSON , I would in the first instance refer to the statement I have just made . I am acquainted with PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON and have no doubts as to their identity . "

In the event , CARDINAL of PERSON CARDINAL questions , most of which concerned the circumstances in which the witness had obtained his / her information , were answered . In this connection Mr GPE added the following in his report :

" The questions sent in , including those from PERSON , which have not been answered were either not asked by me , the examining magistrate , in order to preserve the anonymity of the witness , or not answered by the witness for the same reason . "

CARDINAL . ORG The cases against PERSON , PERSON and PERSON came on for trial before ORG on DATE . Although for procedural reasons each case was dealt with separately and was the subject of a separate judgment , the court held a single sitting , so that the statements made thereat applied to all CARDINAL suspects .

The witnesses heard in court included the examining magistrates PERSON and PERSON ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) and PERSON , CARDINAL of the police officers who had conducted the interview on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . They had been called at the applicant ’s request , but the court , pursuant to LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL ( b ) below ) , did not allow the defence to put to them certain questions designed to clarify the anonymous witnesses’ reliability and sources of information , where answers would have revealed the latter ’s identity .

Mr PERSON stated that he believed the witness he had heard on DATE , who had " made a favourable impression " on him ; that he did not know the witness ’s identity and considered the fear of reprisals advanced in support of his / her wish for anonymity to be a real one ; that he believed the witness had made his / her statement to the police voluntarily ; and that he had refused an offer by the police for him to interview the man they had seen on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) as he could not guarantee the latter ’s anonymity .

PERSON stated that he considered to be " not unreliable " the witness - whose identity he did not know - whom he had interviewed on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) ; and that he too regarded the witness ’s fear of reprisals as well - founded .

PERSON stated that , in his view , the person he had interviewed with a colleague on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) was " completely reliable " because he / she had also given information on other cases which had proved to be correct . He added that certain parts of that person ’s statement had been omitted from the official report in order to protect his / her identity .

CARDINAL . ORG The anonymous witnesses themselves were not heard at the trial . Contrary to a defence submission , the official reports drawn up by the police and the examining magistrates on the hearings of those witnesses were used in evidence . Also the sworn statements made by CARDINAL of them to the magistrates were read out and designated as statements by a witness made at the trial , in accordance with LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

In its judgments of CARDINAL DATE ORG recognised , with regard to the use of the statements of the anonymous witnesses , that their sources of information could not be checked , that it could not form an independent view as to their reliability and that the accused were deprived of the possibility of being confronted with them . By way of justification for its decision nevertheless to use this material in evidence the court stated that it had been convinced of PERSON guilt , considering that the statements strengthened and partly complemented each other and having regard to the views it had heard as to the reliability of CARDINAL of the anonymous witnesses ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . Having also noted that the applicant had previously been found guilty of similar offences , the court convicted him and his co - accused of armed robbery and sentenced each of them to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON , PERSON and PERSON - who have always denied any involvement in the bank raid - appealed to ORG ( Gerechtshof ) , which set aside ORG judgments as it arrived at a different assessment of the evidence . However , after a retrial , at which the CARDINAL cases were dealt with together , ORG , by judgment of CARDINAL DATE , also convicted the applicant and his co - accused and imposed the same sentences as before .

On DATE ORG had heard a number of the witnesses previously heard at first instance , who stood by their earlier testimony . Like ORG , it had not allowed certain questions by the defence to be answered , where this would have revealed the identity of the anonymous witnesses . The following statement had also been made to ORG by Chief PERSON of GPE municipal police :

" Consultations take place before anonymous witnesses are interviewed . It is customary for me to ascertain the identity of the witness to be interviewed in order to assess whether he or she could be in danger . In this case the anonymous witnesses were in real danger . The threat was real . Both witnesses decided to make statements on their own initiative . The public prosecutor was contacted , but I can not remember who it was . The testimony of anonymous witnesses is offered to the examining magistrate after consultation with the public prosecutor . Both anonymous witnesses made a reliable impression on me . "

ORG likewise did not hear the anonymous witnesses but , again contrary to a defence submission , considered the official reports of their interviews with the police and the examining magistrates to be admissible evidence . The court found that the witnesses , who had made their statements on their own initiative , had good reason to fear reprisals ; noted that they had made a reliable impression on PERSON and a reasonably reliable CARDINAL on Mr Nuboer ; and took into account the connections between , and the mutual consistency of , the statements in question .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) dismissed an appeal by the applicant on points of law . It found that ORG had adduced sufficient reasons for admitting the reports in question ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . It also stated that LAW did not prevent a judge , if he deemed it necessary in the interest of the proper administration of justice , from curtailing to some extent the obligation to answer questions and , notably , from allowing a witness not to answer questions about the identity of persons .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , by which time he had served DATE of his prison sentence , PERSON became due for release on parole . However , on DATE he was extradited from the GPE to GPE , to serve there a sentence of CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .
CARDINAL . ORG LAW ( " CCP " ) came into force on DATE . The citations appearing in the present judgment are taken from the ORG as it stood at the time of the applicant ’s trials .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL ORG provides that ORG has CARDINAL or more examining magistrates to whom criminal cases are entrusted . They are nominated , for a term of DATE , by the competent ORG from amongst the members of ORG .

It is open to the public prosecutor , under LAW , to request what is called - in order to distinguish it from the subsequent investigation at the trial - a " preliminary investigation " , which it is the task of an examining magistrate to conduct . In that event the latter will hear the suspect , witnesses and experts as soon as possible and as often as is required ( LAW . Both the public prosecutor and defence counsel are , in principle , entitled to be present at those hearings ( Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) and , even if they are absent , to give notice of questions they wish to have put .

The preliminary investigation provides a basis for a decision with regard to the further prosecution of a suspect and also serves to clarify matters which can not properly be investigated at the trial . The magistrate must act impartially , by collecting also evidence which might exculpate the suspect .

If the public prosecutor is of the opinion that the results of the preliminary investigation justify further prosecution , he will notify the suspect and refer the case to the court . The investigation at the trial will then follow .

CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW , a finding that the accused has been proved to have committed the acts with which he is charged may be made by a judge only if he has been so convinced through the investigation at the trial , by the contents of " legal means of evidence " . The latter consist , according to LAW , exclusively of ( i ) what the judge has himself observed ; ( ii ) statements made by the accused ; ( iii ) statements made by a witness ; ( iv ) statements made by an expert ; and ( v ) written documents .
Evidence in the third category is defined in LAW , which reads :
" CARDINAL . A statement by a witness is understood to be his statement , made in the investigation at the trial , of facts or circumstances which he himself has seen or experienced .
CARDINAL . The judge can not accept as proven that the defendant has committed the act with which he is charged , solely on the statement of CARDINAL witness . "

CARDINAL . Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL - CARDINAL ORG contain various provisions concerning the examination of witnesses at the trial , of which the following are of importance in the context of the present case .

( a ) The president of the court must ask the witness to state , after his first names and surname , his age , occupation and address ( LAW CCP ) ; the same obligation is also laid , by LAW ORG , on an examining magistrate when he is hearing witnesses .

( b ) Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL ORG make it clear that the accused is entitled to put questions to a witness . As a general rule witnesses are examined first by the president of the court ; however , a witness who has not been heard during the preliminary investigation and has been called at the request of the defence will be examined first by the accused and only afterwards by the president ( LAW ORG ) . In any event , LAW ORG empowers the court " to prevent a question put by the accused , counsel for the defence or the public prosecutor being answered " .

( c ) LAW enables the president of the court to order an accused to leave the court - room so that a witness may be examined out of his presence . If such an order - for which reasons do not have to be given - is made , counsel for the defence may question the witness and " the accused shall be told immediately what has happened during his absence and only then will the investigation be resumed " ( LAW ORG ) . Thus , on returning to the court - room the accused may avail himself of his right , under LAW ORG , to put questions to the witness .
CARDINAL . ORG Article CARDINAL ORG provides for an exception to the rule in LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) that witnesses should be heard at the trial . It reads :

" An earlier statement by a witness who , having been sworn in or admonished to speak the truth in accordance with LAW , has died or , in the opinion of the court , is unable to appear at the trial shall be considered as having been made at the trial , on condition that it is read aloud there . "
In connection with witnesses unable to appear at the trial , LAW provides :

" If the examining magistrate is of the opinion that there are grounds for assuming that the witness or the expert will not be able to appear at the trial , he shall invite the public prosecutor , the defendant and counsel to be present at the hearing before him , unless , in the interest of the investigation , that hearing can not be delayed . "
CARDINAL . ORG The fifth category of evidence listed in LAW see paragraph CARDINAL above ) is defined in LAW which , so far as is relevant , reads :
" CARDINAL . By written documents is understood :
CARDINAL ... ;

CARDINAL official reports and other documents , drawn up in the lawful form by bodies and persons who have the proper authority and containing their statement of facts or circumstances which they themselves have seen or experienced ;
CARDINAL ... ;
CARDINAL ... ;
CARDINAL all other documents ; but these are valid only in conjunction with the content of other means of evidence .
CARDINAL . The judge can accept as proven that the defendant has committed the act with which he is charged , on the official report of an investigating officer . "
An anonymous statement contained in an official police report falls within the scope of sub - paragraph CARDINAL of paragraph CARDINAL of this Article .

CARDINAL . ORG In the GPE , the procedure in a criminal case follows in actual practice a course that is markedly different from that suggested by the provisions referred to in DATE above . This is to a considerable extent due to a leading judgment delivered by ORG on DATE , DATE in which the ORG came into force . That judgment ( PERSON ( GPE ) DATE , DATE ) contains the following rulings , each of which is of importance in the context of the present case :

( a ) for a statement by a witness to be considered as having been made at the trial under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , it is immaterial whether or not the examining magistrate has complied with LAW ibid . ) ;
( b ) a deposition by a witness concerning what he was told by another person ( hearsay evidence ) may be used as evidence , albeit with the utmost caution ;
( c ) it is permissible to use as evidence declarations made by the accused or by a witness to a police officer , as recorded in the latter ’s official report .

CARDINAL . ORG These rulings permit the use , as " legal means of evidence " within the meaning of Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , of depositions made by a witness not at the trial but before a police officer or the examining magistrate , provided they are recorded in an official report which is read aloud in court . The rulings have had the effect that in practice the importance of the investigation at the trial - which is never conducted before a jury - has dwindled . In the great majority of cases witnesses are not heard at the trial but either only by the police or also by the examining magistrate .

CARDINAL . ORG The law does not make the presence of counsel for the defence obligatory during the investigation by the police . The same applies to the preliminary investigation by the examining magistrate ( but see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . Nowadays , however , most examining magistrates invite the accused and his counsel to attend when they are hearing witnesses .
CARDINAL . ORG The ORG contains no express provisions on statements by anonymous witnesses .

However , with the increase in violent , organised crime a need was felt to protect those witnesses who had justification for fearing reprisals , by granting them anonymity . In a series of judgments ORG has made this possible .

CARDINAL . ORG A precursor to this development was a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( GPE DATE , CARDINAL ) in which ORG held that hearsay evidence ( see paragraph CARDINAL ( b ) above ) could be admitted even if the witness did not name his informant . Decisions to the same effect have been handed down in the DATE ’s .

In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( GPE DATE , CARDINAL ) , concerning a case where the examining magistrate had granted anonymity to and had heard a witness without the accused or his counsel being present , ORG held - following its judgment of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) - that non - compliance with LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) did not prevent the magistrate ’s official report being used in evidence , " albeit with the caution called for when assessing the probative value of such evidence " . The same ruling was made in a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( GPE DATE , CARDINAL ) , concerning a case where the witness had been heard anonymously by both the police and the examining magistrate ; on that occasion ORG also held - in accordance with its above - mentioned judgment of DATE - that the mere fact that the official reports of the hearings did not name the witness was not an obstacle to their utilisation in evidence , subject to an identical proviso as to caution .

It may be inferred from a judgment of DATE ( GPE DATE , CARDINAL ) that the caution called for does not necessarily imply that anonymous witnesses must have been heard by the examining magistrate also .

The next judgments in the series are those given by ORG on DATE in the cases of PERSON and his co - accused , CARDINAL of which is published in GPE DATE , CARDINAL . They contain the following new elements :
( a ) the mere fact that the examining magistrate did not know the identity of the witness does not prevent the use in evidence of the official report of the hearing he conducted ;

( b ) if the defence contests at the trial the reliability of depositions by an anonymous witness , as recorded in the official report of the hearing of the witness , but the court nevertheless decides to admit them as evidence , it must give reasons justifying that decision .

These principles were confirmed in a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( GPE DATE , CARDINAL ) , which makes it clear that ORG review of the reasons given to justify the admission of anonymous statements as evidence is only a marginal one .

CARDINAL . ORG In their submissions preceding certain of ORG judgments referred to in paragraph CARDINAL above , various Advocates - General , whilst recognising that the granting of anonymity to witnesses could not always be avoided and sometimes had to be accepted as the lesser evil , nevertheless voiced concern . The learned writers who annotated the judgments did likewise , stressing the need for the courts to be very cautious indeed . The judgments have , however , also been criticised .

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE ORG expressed disquiet at the increase in cases in which witnesses were threatened and at the growing number of witnesses who refused to testify unless they were granted anonymity . The ORG recommended that the legislature should direct its attention to the question of anonymous witnesses .

The Minister of ORG consequently set up in DATE an external advisory committee , called " ORG " , to examine the problem . In its report of DATE , which was later submitted for advice to several bodies concerned with the application of the criminal law , the Commission concluded , with CARDINAL member dissenting , as follows :

" In some cases one can not avoid anonymity of witnesses . Reference is made to the fact ( which was also pointed out by the Minister ) that at present there are forms of organised criminality of a gravity that the legislature of DATE would not have considered possible . "

The ORG added that " in a society governed by the rule of law the interference with , or more accurately the frustration of , the course of justice resulting [ from this situation ] can not possibly be accepted " .

The Commission proposed that the law should in principle forbid the use as evidence of statements by anonymous witnesses . It should , however , be possible to make an exception where the witness would run an unacceptable risk if his or her identity were known . In such cases an anonymous statement might be admitted as evidence if the witness had been examined by an examining magistrate , the accused being given a right of appeal against the latter ’s decision to grant anonymity . The report contains a PERSON making the necessary modifications to the ORG ( with draft explanatory notes ) and comparative data .
According to the Government , initiation of legislation in this area has been deferred pending the ORG ’s decision in the present case .
